page.title: 16BIOGRAPHY _continued.
page.content: Her father,a local NUM official at the time lost his post over this incident. He it was who aroused her interest in politics; she joined the Labour Party & helped with the local Co-op. He was one of several instrumental in opening the Workingmen's Club in the 20's, one of the few facilities open in Newfield Mrs Tulip regrets the closing of the mines, yet would not allow her son to work underground. "Too dangerous", she said,"he took up a trade". He is still at home but before retiring was forced to seek employment in Spennymoor. In her youth Mrs Tulip would walk to Willington, crossing the R.Wear by the footbridge, to attend dances and the cinema- once popular, now closed. She is still active in the only remaining chapel, even the school has closed.The village, no longer the vital community she remembers, is still in her blood.
